Acoustical Analysis of a General Network of Multi- Port Elements — An Impedance Matrix Approach

Abstract and Figures

The present work deals with a generalized algorithm for analyzing a network of linear passive acoustic filters having multi-port elements which are interconnected to each other in an arbitrary manner through their respective ports or through general 2-port elements. A multi-port element is characterized by an impedance [Z] matrix, and the junctions through which these multi-port elements are connected are characterized by conditions of continuity of acoustic pressure and mass velocity. A connectivity matrix is written for the entire network, wherein the inter-connections of the elements are taken care of by proper bookkeeping of the acoustic state variables. The acoustic pressures at the external nodes (at the network terminations) are related to mass velocity at the external ports by inversion of the connectivity matrix to obtain the global impedance matrix, characterizing the entire network. This characterization thereby offers a generalized formulation for dealing with a network of multi-port elements. Gener-alized expressions are obtained for determination of the acoustic performance parameters (Transmission loss (TL), Insertion loss (IL), and Level Difference (LD)) for a multi-port system in terms of the [Z] matrix and scattering [S] matrix. A simple method is proposed for evaluation of the [Z] matrices by means of the axial plane wave theory to characterize long chamber mufflers for a uniform area, conical and exponential duct having an arbitrary number of ports, whilst the ports can be located on the end faces as well as on the side surfaces. The [Z] matrices charac-terizing each of these multi-port elements are then used to analyze arbitrary networks of such multi-port elements, and the results are compared with those obtained by 3-D FEA and also against the existing literature.

Acoustical Analysis of a General Network of Multi-
Port Elements — An Impedance Matrix Approach
A. Mimani and M. L. Munjal
Facility for Research in Technical Acoustics, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science,
Bangalore - 560012, India
(Received 15 February 2011; accepted 13 October 2011)
The present work deals with a generalized algorithm for analyzing a network of linear passive acoustic ﬁlters
having multi-port elements which are interconnected to each other in an arbitrary manner through their respective
ports or through general 2-port elements. A multi-port element is characterized by an impedance [Z]matrix, and
the junctions through which these multi-port elements are connected are characterized by conditions of continuity
of acoustic pressure and mass velocity. A connectivity matrix is written for the entire network, wherein the inter-
connections of the elements are taken care of by proper bookkeeping of the acoustic state variables. The acoustic
pressures at the external nodes (at the network terminations) are related to mass velocity at the external ports by
inversion of the connectivity matrix to obtain the global impedance matrix, characterizing the entire network. This
characterization thereby offers a generalized formulation for dealing with a network of multi-port elements. Gener-
alized expressions are obtained for determination of the acoustic performance parameters (Transmission loss (TL),
Insertion loss (IL), and Level Difference (LD)) for a multi-port system in terms of the [Z]matrix and scattering [S]
matrix. A simple method is proposed for evaluation of the [Z]matrices by means of the axial plane wave theory
to characterize long chamber mufﬂers for a uniform area, conical and exponential duct having an arbitrary number
of ports, whilst the ports can be located on the end faces as well as on the side surfaces. The [Z]matrices charac-
terizing each of these multi-port elements are then used to analyze arbitrary networks of such multi-port elements,
and the results are compared with those obtained by 3-D FEA and also against the existing literature.
1. INTRODUCTION
A typical modern day, commercially used, mufﬂer usually
consists of a signiﬁcantly intricate internal structure in which
the acoustic elements are interconnected to each other provid-
ing multiple connections, and thereby facilitating nonunique
paths of wave propagation. The technique of cascading or suc-
cessively multiplying the transfer [T] matrices of 2-port ele-
ments that are connected to each other sequentially (the out-
let of the preceding element is connected to the inlet of the
succeeding element) is the most popular method of analyzing
mufﬂers.1However, a limitation of this approach is that it is
suited only for studying problems in which the direction of
the wave propagation can be predetermined; or in other words,
the acoustic energy propagation is unidirectional. Such an ap-
proach would be useful only if all the elements are connected
in series, or if there is no wave propagation path between two
nonadjacent elements. This feature is illustrated in Fig. 1.
However, in Fig. 2, the acoustic wave propagation direction is
nonunique, inasmuch as junction J2 offers two alternate paths
of wave propagation, thereby making the method of cascading
of transfer matrices inapplicable. This particular arrangement,
in which the elements are not sequentially connected, but inter-
connected amongst themselves so as to facilitate a nonunique
direction of wave propagation, is called a network arrange-
ment.
One of the earlier works in the analysis of acoustic ﬁl-
ters with multiple connections was that of a simple Herschel-
Quincke tube due to Stewart.2Later, Selamet et al. investi-
gated the same problem, wherein they evaluated the acoustic
performance of the Herschel-Quincke tube in terms of Trans-
mission loss (TL) characteristics.3Their work removed the
restrictions on the duct cross-sectional area, and a general an-
alytical expression for TL was derived, based upon the clas-
sical wave equation. Later, Selamet and Easwaran provided a
fairly general extension of the two-duct Herschel-Quincke tube
problem, wherein an N-duct problem was considered.4All the
ducts were connected at one junction, and the second port of
each of these uniform cross-section ducts met at the other junc-
tion, with the lengths of the ducts being unequal, in general.
An analytical expression for TL characteristics was obtained
for a three-duct conﬁguration based upon the classical 1-D
wave propagation equation. Panigrahi and Munjal5later ex-
tended the above work by Selamet and Easwaran4to analyze
a general network of 2-port acoustic ﬁlters interconnected to
each other. They chose to deﬁne their analysis of the network
of 2-port systems as “generalized multiply connected acoustic
ﬁlters.” They argued that instead of considering only uniform
cross-section pipe, a general 2-port network such as an expan-
sion chamber, concentric tube resonators, and extended inlet
and outlet systems, could be considered provided their transfer
matrix was known a priori. Their work was not conﬁned to
analyze only modiﬁed Herschel-Quincke tube conﬁgurations
(where the inlets and outlets of all the Nducts were connected
together), but in general could analyze a network of 2-port ele-
ments connected in an arbitrary manner. However their inves-
tigation was limited to an overall network having only a sin-
gle inlet and single outlet. A general connectivity matrix was
written for the entire network, and the inversion of the same
provided a ﬁnal relation (the overall [T] matrix) between the
state variables at the inlet and the outlet.
International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012 (pp. 2346) 23
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
Figure 1. Example of a system with unique wave propagation path.
Figure 2. Example of a system with nonunique wave propagation path.
The problem of wave propagation in 2-port networks was
also investigated by Glav and Abom6based upon the [S] ma-
trix concept. The travelling wave amplitudes were chosen as
state variables, and each of the 2-port elements was consid-
ered as an active port characterized by a scattering matrix. The
junction (called “node” in their work), although considered as
a multi-port, was treated as a lumped system with the ﬂexibil-
ity of including a source term at each of these junctions. This
work thus had the advantage of including a 2-port source term
within the network, and unlike the earlier works, there was no
restriction that the source term be present at the network termi-
nation ports only. However, their investigation was limited to
computing the travelling plane wave amplitudes, after which,
the other quantities of interest could be evaluated.
A similar work of analyzing an arrangement of silencers of
a general geometry was investigated by Dowling and Peat,7in
which the entire network was subdivided into 2-port systems,
each of which were characterized by transfer matrices. The
nonapplicability of cascading of [T] matrices to analyze the
entire network was discussed when one of the ports of the 2-
port system was connected to two different 2-port subsystems.
In other words, their investigation was conﬁned to the study
of a fork arrangement of one inlet and two outlet subsystems
(i.e., a 3-port junction), wherein a hybrid approach was used
to arrive at the overall 2 ×2 transfer matrix for the entire two
port system.
For more general cases, however, one would encounter a
multi-port junction (conﬂuence of Nports) in a typical network
connection of 2-port acoustic ﬁlters, which implies nonunique-
ness associated with the direction of the wave propagation and
also the nonapplicability of cascading in such a system. Con-
versely, the presence of even one such junction having more
than two ports would destroy the cascading arrangement. A
general N-port junction (multi-port junction) is treated as a
lumped system in references2–6 with the equality of acoustic
pressures at all the ports and sum of the acoustic mass veloci-
ties to be zero, thereby obeying Kirchoff’s laws in an electroa-
coustic analogy representation. In the event of this junction
(which can be likened to be a cavity) where the ports of the 2-
port elements meet (which had earlier been treated as a lumped
system) becoming large enough, the wave propagation effects
within the conﬁnes of the junction cannot be neglected. Thus,
this junction has to be considered as a cavity exhibiting wave
propagation and having multiple ports. This, then, is the be-
ginning of the present investigation, whereby the cavity could
be, in an abstract sense, any acoustic element (large or small
axial length expansion chamber of uniform or gradually vary-
ing cross-section along the axis, with or without extended inlet
and outlet, perforated elements, dissipative linings, etc.). A
method of characterizing this large cavity as a multi-port ele-
ment, having in general Nports, and the analysis of a network
of such multi-port ﬁlters is the subject matter of this present
work.
Recently, Lou et al.8considered this problem of multi-port
element in the form of a simple expansion chamber having
three ports. They constructed different examples of a net-
work with multi-port elements and used the concept of the
impedance [Z] matrix for characterizing each of these ele-
ments. A BEM technique was used for evaluating the [Z] ma-
trix, characterizing each of the subsystem multi-port elements.
However, their work was conﬁned only to some speciﬁc con-
ﬁgurations dealing with three-port systems. Moreover, based
upon their choice of state variables characterizing each of the
subsystem multi-port elements, it can be inferred that at the
junctions the equality of acoustic pressure and conservation of
mass velocity were implied. Thus, in their work only the 2-
port junction is being considered wherein the deﬁnition of the
mass velocity at the ports (in or out) is such that the direction
of the acoustic energy ﬂux is predetermined.
Selamet and Ji9also considered a simple expansion chamber
with two end-inlets and one side-outlet, which can be reckoned
as a multi-port element. Plane wave analysis was used to eval-
uate the TL characteristics of such a system for different ratios
of the incident wave amplitudes at the inlets. Furthermore, the
[Z] matrix for characterizing such a system was obtained using
the BEM technique, and the TL values obtained by the plane
wave approach, as well as the BEM technique, were shown to
compare well. Finally, Selamet and Ji10 also analyzed a circu-
lar expansion chamber with one end-inlet and two end-outlets
using a 3-D analytical approach.
In the recent work of Antebas et al.,11 an expansion cham-
ber of circular cross-section with one end-inlet and double op-
posite end-outlet was analyzed using 3-D analytical method
based upon mode-matching, and the results were compared
with 3-D FEA. An elliptical chamber mufﬂer with a single
end-inlet and double end-outlet on the opposite end plate was
analyzed using 3-D mode-matching by Denia et al.12 The re-
sults were compared with a 3-D FEA showing good agreement,
and some parametric studies regarding the effect of the cham-
ber length, eccentricity as well as positions of inlet and outlet
pipes on the acoustic behaviour, were also done. However, to
the best of the authors’ knowledge, no work is reported on the
characterization of axially long chamber mufﬂers having an ar-
bitrary number of ports (multiple ports) that can be located on
the end faces or on the side surfaces.
Thus, with a view to bridge the gap in the literature regard-
ing the analysis of a general network of multi-port elements as
24 International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
well as to characterize an axially long chamber mufﬂer having
multiple ports, this work aims to:
(1) characterize a general multi-port element (large cavity
within which wave propagation effects have to be consid-
ered) using the [Z] matrix concept;
(2) analyze an arbitrary network of such multi-port elements
interconnected with each other at junctions, either through
their respective ports or through 2-port elements by com-
putation of the global impedance matrix, which thus char-
acterizes the entire system;
(3) obtain generalized expressions for evaluation of the acous-
tic performance of the entire multi-port network in terms
of the Transmission loss (TL), Insertion loss (IL) or Level
Difference (LD);
(4) derive a [Z] matrix to characterize an acoustically long
chamber having multiple ports on the end faces as well as
side faces using the axial plane wave theory; (This cham-
ber can be of uniform cross-section along the length but
can have arbitrary cross-sectional shape; i.e., the cross-
section can be of circular, elliptical or rectangular shape.
In addition, the [Z] matrix based upon axial plane wave
has also been derived for conical and exponential shaped
ducts of circular cross-section and having multiple ports
which can be located on the side (curved surface) or on the
end plate.) and
(5) Validate the multi-port network analysis presented in this
work using the axial plane wave theory with 3-D FEA car-
ried on a commercial software and also against some of
the earlier works in the literature.
In this work, we conﬁne our investigation to the linear
acoustic theory, wherein linearized equations of mass conti-
nuity and momentum are solved in the frequency-domain ap-
proach. Moreover, the mean ﬂow Mach number (Mﬂow) is
taken to be zero, implying that a stationary medium is consid-
ered. Importantly, the convective as well as dissipative effects
of mean ﬂow are also not considered in the present investiga-
tion. However, as an alternative to the linear frequency-domain
approach, the use of nonlinear or ﬁnite amplitude wave theory
is also popular for analyzing commercial mufﬂers.13–17 Here,
one removes the assumption that the acoustic state variables
(acoustic pressure, particle velocity, and density) are small per-
turbations over the corresponding ambient quantities. Rather,
as discussed in Munjal,1one solves the 1-D nonlinear equa-
tions of mass continuity, momentum, and energy balance (tak-
ing into account the effect of wall friction and heat transfer
from the duct walls) by the method of characteristics. Despite
the formidable nature of the nonlinear time-domain approach
as well as the numerical method of the solution, Munjal re-
ports the analysis of rather simple acoustic elements such as
sudden expansion and contraction, extended inlet and outlet,
as well as ﬂow reversal expansion and contraction elements.
However, the use of this 1-D nonlinear time-domain approach
for the analysis of a network of multi-port elements is appar-
ently too complicated, not to speak of the more accurate 3-D
nonlinear time-domain approach! Besides, if one considers the
nonlinear acoustic theory, the [Z] matrix approach presented in
Figure 3. A multi-port element having N+M ports (Direction of mass velocity
considered positive into the system).
this work would be not applicable inasmuch as it is based upon
the linearized acoustic theory. Fortunately, though, unmufﬂed
sound pressure level (SPL) in the internal combustion engines
may be satisfactorily analyzed by means of the linear acoustic
theory—based upon the frequency-domain approach (steady
state response) for analyzing all commercial mufﬂers,1—hence
justifying the use of this approach in the paper. Moreover, it
is assumed that the excitation source can be present only at
the network terminations, or in other words, at the external
ports, thereby rendering each of the multi-port elements of the
network as a passive system. The present work is therefore
particularly suited for the analysis of an automotive mufﬂer
system wherein the excitation source is at the engine exhaust
manifold.
2. IMPEDANCE MATRIX CHARACTERIZA-
TION OF A MULTI-PORT ELEMENT
A multi-port element marked MP having N+Mports is
shown in Fig. 3, wherein the points 1,2, . . . , N +Mlie just
outside the multi-port element and at the beginning of the con-
necting pipes marked as P1, P2, . . . , PN, PN+1, . . . , PN+M
respectively. The acoustic pressures and mass-velocities at the
ports (1 to N+M) of the multi-port element shown in Fig. 3
are related by a [Z] matrix, thereby characterizing the system,
shown hereunder as
{p1. . . pNpN+1 . . . pN+M}T
= [Z](N+M)×(N+M){v1. . . vNvN+1 . . . vN+M}T,(1)
where [Z]is given by Eq. (2) (see on the next page).
Here, piand vi(i= 1 to N+M) are respectively the acous-
tic pressures and mass velocities at the ports. The [Z] parame-
ters can be evaluated using the following relationship:
Zji =pj/vi, i, j = 1,2, . . . , N +M ,
vj= 0 (j6=i), vi6= 0.(3)
An important point deserving a mention here is that the sys-
tem shown in Fig. 3 has been treated as a single multi-port sys-
tem having in general N+Mports, yet this itself can be a com-
plicated network of acoustic elements interconnected amongst
themselves and having N+Mexternal ports or terminations.

3. ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF
MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS
A general network consists of any arbitrary number of multi-
port elements each of which can have an arbitrary number of
ports, and such multi-port elements are connected to each other
through their respective ports or through a general 2-port ele-
ment. The conﬂuence of such ports at which these multi-port
elements are connected are called junctions, which can be of
three types: (1) the ports of only multi-port elements are con-
nected; (2) the ports of only the 2-port elements are connected;
and (3) the ports of both the 2-port elements and the multi-port
elements are connected. Figure 4 illustrates one such junction
wherein the ports of multi-port elements and 2-port elements
are connected.
The junction, in general, is essentially a small cavity
wherein the wave propagation effects are negligible, and thus
Figure 6. The modiﬁed form of the general network of linear passive multi-
port elements.
the cavity can be approximated as a lumped element charac-
terized by equality of acoustic pressures at all the ports (Kir-
choff’s voltage law) and the sum of all the acoustic mass ve-
locity to be zero (Kirchoff’s current law). The external ports
in the network are the points of network terminations, which
could be an outlet, or an inlet wherein a source is located. In
the present work, an external port is directly connected to only
one internal port — one port of a 2-port element or one of the
ports of a general multi-port element. A general network of
multi-port elements is shown in Figs. 5 and 6, wherein the
port numbers are subscripted as efor external ports and ifor
internal ports. It is easy to ﬁgure out from these ﬁgures that an
internal port is directly connected to two or more ports.
A general network can contain Pmulti-port elements with
the ith element containing Pinumber of ports. Hence, the total
number of ports in the network will be
Nt=

twice the number of ports (acoustic pressure and mass veloc-

these multi-port elements could be a general 2-port element or
a simple connecting tube having two ports. Let Qbe the total
number of junctions in the entire network with the jth junction
having Qjnumber of ports. Hence, the total number of ports
due to the junctions will be

It is easy to see that the rth port at the jth junction can be the
sth port of the ith element of the network, thereby providing
a unique connection in the network. Let the total number of
external ports in the network be k, an important consequence

of which is the following relationship:
Mt=Nt−k. (6)
In other words, the total number of ports due to the junctions
is equal to the number of ports in the entire network diminished
by the number of the external ports. Equations (4)–(6) are eas-
ily obtained by investigating any general network of multi-port
elements. A typical junction in a multi-port network can have
Qjports and is characterized by the following equations:

at all the ports of the junctions, and αis the dynamic com-
pliance of the junction (considered as a small cavity). Equa-

within which the wave propagation effects can be ignored at
even higher frequencies, and the volume in general represents
the lumped approximation of a large expansion chamber (hav-
ing in general Qjports) at very low frequencies. Equations
(7) and (8) yield the following [Z] matrix for a small cavity
(having Qjports):

.(9b)
In Eq. (9), [ZJ] is the nondimensionalized impedance ma-
trix for a junction or a small cavity, characterized by unity for
each of its elements. It is interesting to note here that charac-
terization of a small cavity by considering the compliance of
the cavity (howsoever small) as in Eqs. (8) is more accurate
than characterizing the cavity by neglecting the compliance al-
together (implicitly assuming the volume of the cavity, Vc, to
be zero). In this case of zero compliance, the [Z] matrix is not
deﬁned as can be seen from Eqs. (8), because 1/α tends to
inﬁnity (as Vc→0). Thus, setting α= 0 in Eq. (8) along with
Eq. (7) yields the characterization of an M-port junction for
the case of cavity with zero compliance.
In either of the cases, a junction having Qjports is always
characterized by Qjequations, as is evident from either Eqs.
(7) and (8) or Eqs. (9). The summation of mass velocity equal
to zero implies that while analyzing the present network, one
need not be bothered about predetermining the wave propa-
gation direction unlike the previous works of Selamet3,4 and
Panigrahi and Munjal5. In these previous works, the sign of the
acoustic mass velocity was decided by the direction in which
the wave propagation was being considered. In this work,
however, all the mass velocities are reckoned to be positive
when directed into each of the multi-port elements (the ports
of which constitute the junction), so that Eq. (9) is valid. Alter-
natively, if all the mass velocities are considered positive out
of each of the multi-port elements, Eq. (9) would still hold
good, but on the right-hand side of Eq. (9), one would re-
place αwith −α. Another important point worth noting in the
characterization of the junction cavity while considering the
compliance of the cavity is that a junction can also be thought
of as a multi-port element with lumped element approximation
and all mass velocities outside the junction ports considered
positive, as implied in Eqs. (9). This work, unlike the earlier
work of Lou et al.,8thus characterizes a multi-port element
separately and also states the junction laws in an explicit man-
ner, thereby appropriately dealing with a junction having more
than two ports. Also, for a 2-port junction, the compliance is
zero as the 2 nodes at that junction (which form the ports of a
general multi-port element) can be thought of as superposed on
each other. Hence, for a 2-port junction, the [Z] matrix is not
deﬁned, rather the continuity of acoustic pressures and sum-
mation of mass velocity to zero characterize such a junction.
Hence, from the above discussion it is evident that for a gen-
eral network having Mtnumber of total ports at junctions, the
total number of equations would also be Mtwhich in turn is
equal to Nt−k.
It is also seen from Section 2 that a multi-port element hav-
ing Nports is characterized by Nequations, thereby giving us
a total of Ntequations for the entire network. Thus, the total
number of equations for the entire network is 2Nt−k. Hence,
it follows that for a general multi-port network having a to-
tal of Ntports, out of which kports are external ports, there
are 2Ntvariables and 2Nt−kequations. Therefore, from
the theory of linear simultaneous equations it follows that any
2Nt−kvariables out of 2Ntvariables may be expressed as a
linear combination of the remaining kvariables. It is simple to
see that by setting k= 2, one obtains 2Nt−2equations for
an acoustic network with two external ports, that is, the num-
ber of equations is two less than the total number of variables
(acoustic pressure and mass velocities) for the entire network,
an observation which is consistent with the work of Dowling
and Peat.7
Towards this end, the ﬁrst step in analyzing the entire net-
work is to number the nodes (the ordering or numbering of
the nodes could be arbitrary) and deﬁne a connectivity matrix
containing information about the multi-port elements and their
associated connectivity. The connectivity matrix is a square
matrix having dimensions (2Nt−k)×(2Nt−k)as it con-
tains data about the acoustic pressures at the external ports
(pej, j = 1, . . . , k) and the acoustic pressures and mass ve-
locities at the internal ports (pijand vij= 1,2, . . . , Nt−k),
totalling 2Nt−kvariables, and the total number of equations
is also 2Nt−k. Hence, by appropriate bookkeeping of the [Z]
parameters associated with the acoustic state variables at the
internal ports and the acoustic pressure at the external ports,
whilst also considering the junction laws, one obtains a con-
nectivity matrix [C0] (on the LHS of the following equation)
and load matrix [L0]. This load matrix is a rectangular ma-
trix of dimensions (2Nt−k)×k, which contains the coefﬁ-
cients of the acoustic mass velocity at the external ports (i.e.,
vei, i = 1,2, . . . , k) corresponding to each of the 2Nt−k
International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012 27
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
equations. Thus, we have the following system of equations:
[C0](2Nt−k)×(2Nt−k){Λ0}= [L0](2Nt−k)×k{<0},(10)
where
{Λ0}T=npe1. . . pekpi1. . . piNt−k
vi1. . . viNt−ko1×(2Nt−k),
{<0}T=ve1. . . vek1×k.
We brieﬂy describe the algorithm which is used to assemble
the set of (2Nt−k) equations to obtain the overall connectivity
matrix [C0] on the right-hand side and the load matrix [L0] on
the left-hand side. To start with, all the elements of the square
matrix [C0] and the rectangular matrix [L0] are initialized to
zero in the code. It is expedient to mention herein that each
row of these matrices represents one of the 2Nt−kequations
which characterize the overall network, whereas the presence
of a zero in a particular column of each of the rows signiﬁes
that the state variables pijand vij, j = 1,2, . . . , Nt−k;pej
and vej, j = 1,2, . . . , k associated with that particular column
do not feature into that equation. Next, in order to obtain each
of the rows of these matrices, one simply overwrites the zero
in the particular column that pertains to the corresponding state
variable, with consideration of the coefﬁcient associated with
that state variable in the equation. This process is repeated
until one obtains all the 2N−krows of each of the [C0] and
[L0] matrices. Finally, by inverting [C0] in Eq. (10) and then
premultiplying with [L0], one gets
{Λ0}= [R0](2Nt−k)×k{<0},
[R0] = [C0]−1[L0].(11)
From Eq. (11) it is straightforward to see that the ﬁrst krows
of [R0] would represent acoustic pressures at the external ports
as a linear combination of the mass velocities at the external
ports, thereby yielding
pe1. . . pekT= [Zglobal]k×kve1. . . vekT.
(12)
In Eq. (12), [Zglobal] is the overall impedance matrix charac-
terizing the entire network of multi-port elements, wherein the
acoustic pressures at the external ports are related to the mass
velocities at the external ports. It is important to note that the
order in which the acoustic pressures at the external ports and
state variables at the internal ports are arranged need not be the
same as in Eqs. (10) and (11). For instance, pe2could be the
last, or pi1could be the ﬁrst. However, for obtaining the global
impedance matrix as shown in Eq. (12), the same row should
be chosen in the rectangular matrix [R0] for Eq. (11) as the one
that corresponds to the acoustic pressure at the external port in
the vector on the left-hand side in Eq. (11). This arrangement
of the acoustic pressure at the external ports in the ﬁrst few
rows as shown in Eq. (10) gives one the advantage of restruc-
turing the connectivity matrices [C0] and [L0] into submatrices
as shown in Eqs. (13):
[C0] = [C0A]k×k[C0B]k×k1
[C0C]k1×k[C0D]k1×k1,
[L0] = [L0A]k×k
[L0B]k1×k, k1= 2 (Nt−k).(13)
Thus, the solution of Eq. (10) can now be rewritten in terms
of the sub-matrices as shown hereunder
[R0] = [R0A]k×k
[R0B]k1×k=
=[Γ0] [L0A]−[C0A]−1[C0B] [Ψ0] [L0B]
−[C0D]−1[C0C] [Γ0] [L0A] + [Ψ0] [L0B],(14)
where
Γ0=h[C0A]−[C0B] [C0D]−1[C0C]ik×k−1
,
Ψ0=h[C0D]−[C0C] [C0A]−1[C0B]ik1×k1−1
.
Hence, the [Zglobal] matrix in Eq. (12) is equal to the subma-
trix [R0A] in Eq. (14). It is worthwhile to notice that the above
equations are merely another way of presenting acoustic state
variables at the internal ports and acoustic pressure at the exter-
nal ports as a linear combination of acoustic mass velocities at
the external ports. The matrix partitioning in Eqs. (13–14) may
not give us a signiﬁcant computational advantage for a network
with a relatively fewer number of ports, but it may help in bet-
ter conceptualization. Therefore, instead of directly inverting
a large connectivity matrix, one can invert smaller submatrices
of dimensions k×kand k1×k1and then premultiply the same
with the submatrices [L0A] and [L0B] in Eqs. (13) in order to
get the overall impedance matrix, [R0A].
4. AN ILLUSTRATION

linear acoustic ﬁlters having multi-port elements, an arbitrary
network is considered as shown in Fig. 5. We follow an arbi-

in this example. However, we choose to add the sufﬁx eto
all the external ports and sufﬁx ito all the internal nodes, as
discussed earlier. The [Z] matrices for the multi-port elements
(marked as MP1 and MP2 in Fig. 5) are written ﬁrst, followed
by the [Z] matrices for the 2-port elements (marked as TP1,
TP2 ,..., TP7 in Fig. 5). Then, the junction laws are writ-
ten for each of the junctions in the network. However, as per
the discussion in Section 3, compliance of the junction cav-
ity is considered only for junctions having three or more ports.

The general 2-port elements in Fig. 5 could be a simple con-
necting pipe, expansion chamber, extended tube elements, con-
centric perforated resonator, gradually varying tube, or even a
chamber with absorptive linings. The analysis of such a net-
work can be done by considering 3-D wave propagation in the
multi-port elements or even in a general 2-port element, but
for the 2-port element comprising of only the connecting pipes
through which each of the multi-port elements are connected,
it is assumed that only planar wave propagation would take
place. In the set of equations for Eq. (17), α5is the com-
pliance of the 3-port junction J5. For the multi-port network
considered in this case, we have 21 ports (17 internal ports and
4 external ports), thereby giving a total of 42 state variables.
Also, the total number of equations, considering only the
multi-port elements, is 7, while the number of equations for all
the 2-port elements adds up to 14. Also, considering the junc-
tion laws, we have an additional 17 equations, thereby giving
us a total of 38 equations for the present network. This network
has 4 external ports, hence the number of equations (or inter-
relations between the state variables) should be 42 −4 = 38
as per the discussion in Section 2, which is indeed the case,
thereby conﬁrming the correctness of the above analysis. Use
of Eqs. (15), (16) and (17) and appropriate bookkeeping of
the network connections yields the overall connectivity matrix
[C0] for the entire network. Thus,
[C0]38×38 {Λ0}= [L0]38×4{<0},(18)

the 2-port elements). One such example is illustrated in Fig.

the equations from the set of Eqs. (15–17) are to be modiﬁed,
while others are unchanged, and some additional ones have to
be considered. The additional equations to be considered are:

Thus, the objective of characterizing a general network of
multi-port elements (connected amongst themselves in an ar-
bitrary manner) is realized by means of an overall impedance
matrix — once the impedance matrix characterizing each of
the multi-port elements of the network is known. It is im-
portant to note here that for the case of the modiﬁed network
International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012 29
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
considered in Fig. 6, the number of external variables in the
network (four in this case) remains the same as in the original
network shown in Fig. 5, thereby rendering the dimensions of
the global impedance matrix in Eq. (23) unaltered. However,
the present algorithm is general enough that one can modify
the original network in Fig. 5 to model a more complex con-
ﬁguration — to have either more or less of a number of exter-
nal variables in the modiﬁed network, and yet obtain the new
overall impedance matrix.
Another interesting feature of the present work is that in-
stead of characterizing the 2-port elements by impedance ma-
trices, one may also characterize them by transfer matrices,
as shown by Panigrahi and Munjal.5It is also imperative to
mention herein that for a network comprising of only 2-port
elements but having more than two external ports, the overall
network must be characterized by a [Z] matrix. Albeit in a
special case of a 2-port network having an even number of ex-
ternal ports, the overall transfer matrix may be obtained from
the overall [Zglobal] matrix by using the interchangeable rela-
tions between these two matrix representations as discussed in
Easwaran et al.11 Alternatively, the overall transfer [T] matrix
may directly be obtained by deﬁning [C0] and [L0], such that
one solves for acoustic pressure and mass velocities at half of
the external ports and all the interior ports as a linear combi-
nation of acoustic pressure and mass velocities at the remain-
ing half of the external ports. The [T] matrix so obtained is
nonunique as it depends upon the choice of the external ports
chosen. However, the [Zglobal] matrix is unique. Similarly, for
a network of multi-port elements (having more than two ports)
having an even number of external ports, it is possible to write
a [T] matrix representation for the overall network. As a corol-
lary of the above discussion, if a multi-port element network
has only two external ports, then the overall network always
has a [T] matrix representation. However, the use of [T] ma-
trix in a multi-port element network does not necessarily give
one an advantage unless the network arrangement is such that
it allows cascading.
In view of the application of the general network of multi-
port elements for an automotive exhaust system, it is worth-
while to note that in Eqs. (19) and (23) characterizing the en-
tire network, the number of inlet-ports can be arbitrary, while
the remaining external ports can be regarded as outlet-ports.
5. PROCEDURE FOR COMPUTATION OF
TRANSMISSION LOSS (TL)
An arbitrary network of multi-port elements having (N+M)
external ports (Ninlet and Moutlet) is considered which is
characterized by an overall [Z] matrix of size (N+M)×(N+
M). The relation between the [Z] matrix and [S] matrix is
established ﬁrst. Then, it is extended to the deﬁnition of TL for
a general Ninlet and Moutlet system. Toward this end, we
assume that external ports of the network consist of uniform
pipes of small diameters (simple tubular elements) in which
only planar waves exist, broadly covering the entire frequency
region of interest for an automotive mufﬂer. The [Z] matrix is
written as
p1. . . pNpN+1 . . . pN+MT=
= [Z](N+M)×(N+M)v1. . . vNvN+1 . . . vN+MT.
(24)
We place sources at all the N+Mports and denote the
incident progressive waves (directed into the system) as Ai,
while the progressive waves reﬂected from the system (in the
outward direction) are denoted as Bi, where i= 1,2, . . . , N +
M. Thus, one gets the following set of equations:

Incidentally, it is observed that relational forms between the
[S] matrix and the [Z] matrix shown in Eqs. (30) and (31)
are essentially the same as the ones observed by Easwaran.18
However, those relations were in the form of submatrices of
the [Z] matrix and [S] matrix rather than the more compact
form presented above, which permits easy computation of the
scattering matrix once the impedance matrix characterizing the
entire network is known. Thus, one is in a position to compute
or rather extend the deﬁnition of TL for a general multiple inlet
(Ninlets) and multiple outlet (Moutlets) (MIMO) system. We
consider Nsources at the ﬁrst N(inlet) ports, while anechoic
termination is imposed at the remaining M(outlet) ports, so
that Ai= 0, for i=N+1, . . . , N +M. Hence, the [S] matrix
reduces to a rectangular matrix, wherein the reﬂected waves
at the outlet-ports are expressed as a linear combination of the
ratios of the incident wave amplitudes at the inlets, normalized
with respect to one of the incident wave amplitudes, say A1, to
yield the following:
B1=A1{S11 +λ12S12 +. . . +λ1NS1N},
. . . ,
BN=A1{SN1+λ12SN2+. . . +λ1NSN N },(32)
BN+1 =A1{S(N+1)1 +λ12S(N+1)2 +. . . +λ1NS(N+1)N},
. . . ,
BN+M=A1{S(N+M)1 +λ12S(N+M)2 +. . . +λ1nS(N+M)N}.
(33)
In Eqs. (32) and (33), we have λ12 =A2/A1, λ13 =
A3/A1, . . . , λ1N=AN/A1.Thus, the TL for this MIMO sys-
tem is deﬁned as follows:
T L =10log10 (Etotal_incident /Etotal_transmitted),(34)
where
Etotal_incident =|A1|2/2ρ0n(1/Y1) + |λ12|2/Y2+
+. . . +|λ1N|2/YNo,(35)
Etotal_transmitted = (1/2ρ0)n|BN+1|2/YN+1 +
+|BN+2|2/YN+2 +. . . +|BN+M|2/YN+Mo.(36)
In Eqs. (35) and (36), ρ0is the ambient density of the
medium. Alternatively, one can compute the total energy in-
cident at the inlet-ports and the total energy reﬂected from the
outlet-ports in the form of submatrices of the [S] matrix, al-
though these details are not shown here for reasons of brevity.
It is easy to see from the foregoing discussion that the TL can
be computed for a general MIMO system, whereas the earlier
work of Lou et al.8in which the TL is computed for a single
inlet (N= 1) and double outlet (M= 2) system is actually
a special case of the more general approach presented in this
work. The case of a chamber with two end-inlets and one side-
outlet analyzed by Selamet and Ji9is also a special case of this
work wherein N= 2 and M= 1. In this work, however, an
explicit expression for TL in terms of the [Z] matrix for a gen-
eral multiple inlet (N) and multiple outlet (M) system is not
presented. Rather, TL is deﬁned in terms of the [S] parameters.
The reason for this can be attributed to the algebraic tedious-
ness of inverting the matrix (Z[Y]−1+I) for the generic case
of an (N+M) port system and the subsequent premultiplica-
tion with the matrix (Z[Y]−1-I) on the right-hand side.
Nonetheless, it is easy to appreciate from Eqs. (32–36) that
the computation of TL is more convenient from the point of
view of algebraic manipulation in terms of the [S] matrix since
it uses a progressive wave characterization for a general multi-
port system which has (N+M) ports, wherein the reﬂected
wave amplitudes are expressed as a linear combination of the
incident wave amplitudes at all (N+M) ports. Consequently,
the advantage of computing the TL by ﬁrst obtaining the [S]
matrix can be seen from the fact that for different choices of
inlet and outlet-ports, the computation of TL for the entire sys-
tem can be affected by simply using the appropriate [S] param-
eters. As an illustration, we consider a single inlet and single
outlet (SISO) system as well as a single inlet and double outlet
(SIDO) system, respectively. Hence, for a SISO system, one

following condition:

making use of Eq. (41) although the same is not shown here
for reasons of brevity.

It is also worth mentioning that the TL is not dependent upon
the absolute amplitude of the incident wave at any of the inlets,
but depends only upon the ratio of the relative amplitudes of
the incident waves at the inlet-port as was shown in Eqs. (32–
36). Moreover, it is also important to note that in Eqs. (32–36),
one may consider inlet sources with the ratio of the incident
waves (λ21, λ31, . . . , λN1) at the inlet to be constant over the
entire frequency range of interest, or that in general, one may
have these ratios to be functions of frequency depending upon
the type of inlet source characteristics; that is, one may have
constant pressure sources (Zsi = 0, i = 1,2, . . . , N ), con-
stant volume velocity sources (Zsi → ∞, i = 1,2, . . . , N )
or in general sources having an arbitrary source impedance
(Zsi, i = 1,2, . . . , N ).
6. PROCEDURE FOR COMPUTATION
OF INSERTION LOSS (IL)
This section outlines the procedure for the computation of
Insertion loss (IL) for a MIMO system (ﬁrst Nports are inlet-
ports and remaining Mports are outlet-ports as in the case of
TL computations) with the inlet sources having general source
characteristics ps,Zs). The Thevenin’s form (pressure rep-
resentation) as well as the Norton’s form (velocity represen-
tation) of a general MIMO system may be constructed from
Figs. 2.5a and b of Ref. 1. Instead of one acoustic pressure
source (ps1,Zs1) and velocity source (vs1=ps1/Zs1)on the
left-hand side or upstream of the SISO element in Figs. 2.5a
and b, one has Nsuch sources. Similarly, at the right-hand
side or downstream of the MIMO element, one has Mradia-
tion impedances corresponding to the Moutlet-ports instead
of just one radiation impedance as shown in Fig. 2.5a and
b. Even though, the ﬁgures corresponding to the Thevenin’s
form and the Norton’s form are not shown for the reasons of
brevity, we introduce the following symbols for the sake of
clarity and completeness. The source characteristics for the N
inlet sources corresponding to the Thevenin’s form are denoted
by (ps1,Zs1, ps2,Zs2, . . . , psN ,ZsN where ps1represents
source pressures and Zsi represents the source impedances for
32 International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
i= 1,2, . . . , N . Similarly, ζ1, ζ2, . . . , ζNare the acoustic
impedances at the inlet-ports in the Norton’s form and the mass
velocity sources are denoted by vsi for i= 1,2, . . . , N. The
corresponding mass velocity in terms of source characteristics
and acoustic pressure at the inlet are shown as follows:
vsi =psi/Zsi , vi= (psi −pi)/Zsi, i = 1,2, . . . , N (45)
At the outlet-ports, one changes the sign convention of the
acoustic mass velocities so that everywhere direction of the
mass velocity is taken to be positive outside the system, and
the corresponding radiation impedance condition is imposed
so that
pN+j/vN+j=Z0,(N+j), j = 1,2, . . . , M (46)
with Z0,(N+j)representing the radiation impedance at the
outlet-ports. Thus, using Eqs. (24), (45) and (46), one obtains

In Eq. (53), E1total represents the power radiated without the
ﬁlter, E2total represents the power radiated with the ﬁlter, and
R0,i denotes the real part of the radiation impedance Z0,i at
each of the ports with i= 1,2, . . . , N +M. Once the acoustic
pressures at the outlet-ports are evaluated from Eqs. (47–49),
the mass velocities at the outlet-ports (vN+j,j= 1,2, . . . , M )
can be found out by means of Eq. (46). It is also seen from
Eqs. (50–54) that like the TL, the IL is not dependent upon
the absolute value of the acoustic source pressures, rather it
depends only upon the normalized source pressures at the inlet-
ports.
We brieﬂy present the special case of Eqs. (47–54), wherein
the inlet sources have inﬁnite impedance, (i.e., Zs→ ∞), or in
other words they are constant volume velocity sources.1How-

volume velocity, hence vsi (i= 1,2, . . . , N ) in the ensuing
equations denote constant mass velocities. Thus, we modify
Eqs. (47–49) to yield

inlet and outlet-ports as a linear combination of the constant

sources. It is again evident that IL is a function of the ratio of
the mass velocities at inlet-ports and not the absolute value of
the mass velocity. Similarly, the procedure to compute IL for
the case of all inlet sources having zero impedance (constant
pressure sources) may also be worked out with the help of Eqs.
(24) and (46) and by considering Thevenin’s representation of
the sources. However, the details are not presented here for
reasons of brevity.
As in the case of TL (Section 5.1, Eqs. (42–44)), one may
replace TL with IL, to obtain exactly identical relations for IL
for the entire system between a pair of inlet and outlet-ports for
a general MIMO acoustic system, even though these relations
are not presented for the sake of brevity.
7. COMPUTATION OF LEVEL
DIFFERENCE (LD)
We ﬁnd an expression for the Level Difference (LD) be-
tween a pair of inlet and outlet-ports for a general Ninlet and
Moutlet system. The acoustic pressure at the ith inlet-port and
jth outlet-port, where 1≤i≤Nand 1≤j≤Mare found
using Eqs. (50) and (51) in Section 6 as shown hereunder:
pi=ps1{R2(i, 1) + η21R2(i, 2) + . . . +ηn1R2(i, N )},
pN+j=ps1nR2(N+j, 1) + η21R2(N+j, 2) +
+. . . +ηn1R2(N+j, N )o.(61)
We get an expression for the LD between the ith inlet-port
and jth outlet-port as1
LDi(N+j)= 20 log10 (|pi/pN+j|).(62)
It is also worth noting that the LD between the aforesaid
ports is the limiting case of IL between the same ports in the
case of constant pressure source at that particular inlet-port (ith
port) with the two pipe diameters for the respective ports being
equal. This can be easily seen by setting the source impedance
Zsi = 0 and evaluating the acoustic power radiated out with-
out the ﬁlter by the ith inlet source and acoustic power radi-
ated from the jth outlet-port.1Generalizing, out of the Ninlet
sources, if the ith inlet source is a constant pressure source, then
the LD between that inlet port and any of the outlet ports is the
same as IL between the same pair of inlet and outlet ports, pro-
vided that the diameters of both ports are the same. Thus for a
constant pressure source at the ith inlet-port, one gets
LDij = (ILij)limZsi →0,∀N+ 1 ≤j≤N+M, di=dj.
(63)

A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
In Eq. (63), the subscript ij stands for the ith inlet-port and
jth outlet-port, and dis the diameter of the ports. For the case
of a SISO system, we get the following expression for LD:

served for the case of LD for the general case of a MIMO sys-
tem:
(i) LD is independent of the source characteristics for a
SIMO system. However, the knowledge of the radiation
impedance at the outlet ports is required in computation
of the same1; and
(ii) For the case of multiple inlet system, the LD would
depend upon the ratio of the acoustic source pressures
(η12, η13 , . . . , η1N) and also on the source impedances
(Zs1, Zs2, . . . , ZsN ).
8. AXIAL PLANE WAVE ANALYSIS
OF A MULTI-PORT ELEMENT
As an illustration of the general formulation to character-
ize a multi-port element in Section 2, an axially long cavity
having four ports (one port on each of the end faces and the re-
maining two ports on the side faces at different distances along
the length) is considered as shown in Fig. 7a, with the cross-
sectional area gradually varying along the axis in an arbitrary
manner. We characterize this system by a [Z] matrix using
the axial plane wave theory. To obtain the [Z] parameters for
the ﬁrst column, we block the ports marked as 2, 3 and 4 in
Fig. 7a and excite the system at port 1. This is illustrated in
Fig. 7b. However, to account for the evanescent modes gen-
erated at the port 1, we consider the port 1 to be protruded
into the chamber by a small amount δ1(often described as the
end-correction). Similar treatment of end correction effects are
found in the works of Torregrosa et al.,20 wherein the effective
length of the extended inlet was slightly greater than the physi-
cal length due to nonplanar behaviour at the area discontinuity.
Karal21 and Lung and Doige22 considered a similar end correc-
tion to account for lumped inertial effects (Lkaral) of higher or-
der modes at the junction by obtaining the [T] matrix at an area
discontinuity. Similarly, end corrections at the port located on
a
b
Figure 7. (a) An acoustically long chamber of gradually varying cross-
sectional area having multiple (four) ports. (b) An illustration demonstrating
the characterization of an acoustically long chamber mufﬂer: Excitation at Port
1 while rest of the ports (2, 3 and 4) are blocked.
the opposite end face, (i.e., port 2) is also accounted for by
considering a small protruding length δ2. We assume rigid end
faces (sections marked as XX and YY in Fig. 7b) and rigid side
walls for the system considered. First, the [T] matrix relations
between the various sections shown in Fig. 7b are obtained,
which are based upon the sign convention following Munjal1.
This basis follows the convention in that the direction of veloc-
ity is considered positive into the system upstream, while the
direction of the velocity downstream is reckoned to be positive
out of the system. As a result of this, the velocity is considered
positive into the system at ports 1 and 1a, while the impedance
of the small cavity formed at port 1 due to the end correction
is positive looking into the cavity. The [T] matrices are then
listed, along with compatibility conditions between the various
sections as follows:

It is imperative here to mention that the effects of end cor-
rections are more signiﬁcant for ports located on the end face,
and therefore, the analysis shown in the preceding paragraphs
is justiﬁed. However, while dealing with the ports located on
36 International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012

the side or curved surfaces, the pressure response is actually
measured along the length of the chamber, corresponding to
the location of the center of the side port. Nevertheless, in the
ensuing validation, the effects of end corrections in the con-
necting pipes between different multi-port elements are always
considered wherein, following Karal,21 the acoustic length of
the pipe is slightly greater than the physical length due to the
generation of higher order evanescent modes at the area dis-
continuities.
Thus, making use of the expressions derived for the [Z] pa-
rameters above for a duct with arbitrarily (but gradually) vary-
ing cross-sectional area, we present below the [Z] parameters
for the case of uniform chambers of circular, elliptical, and
rectangular cross-sectional areas, followed by conical and ex-
ponential shaped ducts of circular cross-section, respectively,
corresponding to the conﬁguration shown in Fig. 7a. However,
for reasons of algebraic complexity, we present the effects of
end corrections only for the case of uniform area ducts.

In principle, one may also use the axial plane wave analysis
to obtain [Z] parameters for a parabolic and hyperbolic shaped
duct25 having multiple ports located arbitrarily either on the
end faces or on the side surfaces. Similarly, one may also ob-
tain [Z] matrix parameters for a uniform cylindrical chamber
having multiple extended inlet and outlet-ports as well as per-
forated elements, although we do not present the [Z] matrix
formulation for these elements in the present work.
9. ADVANTAGES OF IMPEDANCE MATRIX
CHARACTERIZATION
Some of the advantages of characterizing an acoustically
long chamber by [Z] matrix based upon the axial plane wave
theory are discussed as follows. Firstly, the [Z] parameters of
a multi-port element can be obtained by a mere inspection of
the locations of the ports (as that would yield the [Z] param-
eter (Zij ) between the two ports) by making use of the axial
plane wave analysis (up to about the cut-on frequency of the
ﬁrst higher order mode) for the cases of uniform, conical, ex-
ponential, parabolic and hyperbolic shaped ducts. It is also
obvious that by making use of the relevant sets of expressions
of Zij given above in Section 8, any variable area duct having
multiple ports can be analyzed, provided the variation of the
cross-sectional area is known a priori as a function of the axial
coordinate. For duct shapes whose analytical solution cannot
be obtained in terms of the already known functions (e.g., cir-
cular functions or cylindrical functions like Bessel functions),
one may resort to 1-D numerical techniques like the Matrizant
approach26 to compute the [T] matrices between different sec-
tions shown in Fig. 7b, and thence follow the procedure de-
scribed in Section 2 to obtain the [Z] parameters. However,
when the cross-sectional area tends to zero at either or both
the ends for the duct conﬁguration shown in Fig. 7a, one may
not use the [T] matrix relations and the corresponding gener-
alized [Z] parameters derived in Section 8, but use a modiﬁed
form of these equations (not shown here). This is typically the
case for the transverse plane wave analysis of short elliptical or
circular chambers with multi-ports wherein there is dominant
transverse/diametral plane wave propagation.26–28
The procedure of characterizing a general multi-port ele-
ment comprising a rigid wall cavity by a [Z] matrix offers an
inherent advantage, inasmuch as blocking all the ports of the
cavity and exciting the system at one of the ports leads to a ho-
mogenous rigid-walled condition at the boundaries. Here, one
is assuming that all the ports of the cavities are blocked just
at the junctions of the connecting pipes. Thus, the pressure
response at any arbitrary point at the rigid wall of the cavity
(which can be likened to be a blocked port centered on that
38 International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
point) can be obtained due to the excitation at the inlet-port.
Consequently, the [Z] parameter corresponding to the inlet at
the excitation port and pressure response at that point can be
obtained irrespective of the location of any other port on the
rigid walls of the cavity. This not only simpliﬁes the algebra
considerably but also provides for an easy manipulation of the
original [Z] matrix to obtain a new [Z] matrix if one or more
extra ports are connected at any arbitrary location on the rigid-
walled cavity. The above discussion is especially applicable
when the end correction effects are not considered within the
chamber, but only considered at the junctions of the connecting
pipes. To elucidate this important concept, we obtain the [Z]
matrix corresponding to the conﬁguration shown in Fig. 7a for
the case of a uniform expansion chamber, shown as follows:
p1p2p3p4T= [Z1]4×4v1v2v3v4T,
(125)
where [Z1]is given by Eq. (126) (see on the next page).
We now consider adding one extra port, say at the end face
where the port 1 is located, and we will call this newly added
port as port 5. As per the earlier discussion, it is easily under-
stood that the new system can be characterized appended by an
extra column and row containing the corresponding [Z] param-
eters to the matrix [Z1]. Thus, the [Z] matrix for the modiﬁed
system is shown as
p1p2p3p4p5T=
= [Z2]5×5v1v2v3v4v5T,(127)
where [Z2]is given by Eq. (128) (see on the next page).
At this stage, it is expedient to mention here that even when
the end correction in the chamber is considered, the above ar-
gument still holds good inasmuch as we need to use the [Z]
parameters shown in Eqs. (119) instead of those shown in Eq.
(128). An approximate expression is obtained to determine the
value of the protruding length δ1, due to more than one port
being located at an end face. Following Lung and Doige22 and
extending the idea of lumped inertial effects of the higher or-
der evanescent modes due to multiple discontinuities at an end
face, we obtain an approximate expression for δ1for the case of
Nports located at an end plate. This expression seems to work
reasonably well at lower frequencies up to the cut-on frequency
of the ﬁrst higher order mode as will be evident from the ensu-
ing TL predictions shown in the following section. Thus, we
have
δ1= 0.85 (deq/2) (1 −deq /D0),
deq =qd2
1+d2
2+... +d2
N.(129)
In Eqs. (129), D0is the diameter of the chamber at that
end face where the ports are located. Thus, when the ef-
fects of end corrections in the chamber are considered, the pa-
rameters of [Z1] matrix will only be slightly different in Eq.
(126), than those in Eq. (128), although the forms of these
[Z] parameters would be the same. This is due to the fact
that by adding one extra port at that end face, the value of δ1
is slightly increased, thereby affecting the [Z1] sub-matrix in
Eq. (128), only marginally. Moreover, the aforementioned ad-
vantages offered by the [Z] matrix to characterize multi-port
chambers also holds if one uses the transverse plane wave the-
ory to characterize axially short multi-port elliptical chamber
mufﬂers,25–27 and also if one considers 3-D wave propagation
inside multi-port chamber mufﬂers by means of an analytical
approach based upon the uniform piston-driven model and the
modal expansion technique (for geometries in which the 3-D
Helmholtz equation is separable29). However, the foregoing
advantages are restricted up to the cut-on frequency of the ﬁrst
higher order mode in the ports, as the assumption of only pla-
nar waves in the ports is implicit in the present analysis.
Another important point worth mentioning here is that when
an axial plane wave is used to characterize long-chamber
multi-port elements, the presence of two or more ports at the
same end face or at the same location along the side or curved
surface would render the [Z] matrix singular. Hence, the ad-
mittance matrix characterization is not possible for such a con-
ﬁguration. It is easily discernible that [S] matrix characteriza-
tion of a general multi-port element can also be obtained by
exciting the system at one of the ports and applying anechoic
termination at rest of the ports. Thence, by evaluating the ratio
Bi/Aj, (i.e., the ratio of the reﬂected wave at the port ito the
incident wave at port j), one can evaluate the [S] parameter
Sij , whereby one can directly obtain the [S] matrix instead of
the [Z] matrix. However, deriving the [S] matrix parameters is
generally more tedious, purely from a theoretical (analytical)
angle in view of the inhomogeneous boundary conditions asso-
ciated with the characterization. Hence, one may conclude that
the [Z] matrix is simpler and better suited to analytically char-
acterize a general multi-port element while the [S] matrix is
ideally suited for obtaining the acoustic performance in terms
of TL.
10. VALIDATION OF THE MULTI-PORT
NETWORK ANALYSIS
The axial plane wave analysis of a multi-port element of dif-
ferent ﬂow ducts presented in the previous section is now used
to analyze arbitrary networks of multi-port elements, and the
results are compared with the 3-D FEA carried on commercial
software.

and MP2, each having four ports and each connected to each
other by three connecting pipes (2-port elements). The inlet
(P1) and outlet (P2) ports for this SISO system are also indi-
cated in Fig. 8. The [Z] matrices characterizing each of the
multi-port elements as well as the 2-port elements are written,
following which the [Zglobal] matrix is obtained as follows:

Finally, the TL is computed in terms of the [Z] parameters
for this SISO system and the results are shown in Fig. 9. It
is seen that the resonance peak occurs at certain frequencies
due to phase differences in the progressive wave amplitudes
induced by the unequal lengths of the connecting pipes be-
tween the two multi-port elements. The TL predicted by the
axial plane wave analysis matches satisfactorily with the 3-D
FEA, up to about the cut-on frequency of (1, 0) mode, which
in this case is 1607 Hz. Also, it has been observed that the ef-
fect of end corrections within the chamber is rather marginal,
whereas the increase in acoustic length of the connecting pipes,
accounted by considering Eqs. (143) and (144), is more impor-
tant, inasmuch as the resonance peak at about 900 Hz is satis-
factorily captured by the axial plane wave predictions. The
40 International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration, Vol. 17, No. 1, 2012
A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .
Figure 8. Multi-port Network – 1 with the following dimensions of the mufﬂer elements: d1= 0.04 m, d2=d3=d4= 0.025 m, d5= 0.04 m, l1= 0.1m,
l2= 0.205 m, l3= 0.150 m, l4= 0.230 m, l5= 0.1m, D0= 0.125 m, L1= 0.25 m, L2= 0.3m, δ1= 0.035 m, δ2= 0.04 m.
sound speed c0= 343.14 ms−1in computing the TL for this
multi-port network, as well as the cases dealt hereafter. It is
indeed very important to observe a rather subtle property of
the axial plane wave analysis of the network shown in Fig. 8.
This is brought to light by considering each of the multi-port
elements (MP1 and MP2) as 2-port elements having a four port
junction near the end face (three ports of the connecting pipes
and one port of the multi-port chamber). Thus, following this
approach one may consider the conﬁguration shown in Fig.
8 to be a network of 2-port elements analyzed by Panigrahi
and Munjal.5We do not present the corresponding equations
for this approach, rather merely state that the axial plane wave
analysis of a multi-port element by the [Z] matrix is indeed
equivalent, in principle, to the approach of considering the
chamber as a sequence of 2-port elements having junctions at
the end faces and side-ports where the ports of the connecting
pipes meet. In fact, if the lengths and diameters of the connect-
ing pipes of the elements TP2, TP3, and TP4 in Fig. 8 are the
same, then the multi-port analysis can be replaced by consider-
ing a connecting pipe of equivalent diameter within the scope
of axial plane wave analysis. However, in case the lengths
or the diameters are different, the present approach must be
adopted.
Indeed, the characterization of a single multi-port element
(This element could also be one of the elements in a network)
using an axial plane wave analysis having two or more outlet-
ports located (1) on the same end plate (The offset distances
and angular orientation are not considered), and (2) on the side
surface at equal distances along the length of the chamber, can
also be effected by considering an equivalent single port of
a cross-sectional area equal to the sum of the cross-sectional
areas of the two or more outlet-ports located at that section, as
discussed in Selamet and Ji.6However, in the event of these
ports being located at the same section but connected to some
different multi-port element with connecting pipes of unequal
lengths, one must make use of the [Z]-matrix-based multi-port
analysis presented in this work to characterize the respective
multi-port element.
The equations characterizing the multi-port elements of the
network and also the junction laws for each of the ensuing
cases of multi-port network will not be shown for the sake of
brevity.

Multi-port Network – 2 shown in Fig. 10: Validation of axial plane wave anal-
ysis with 3-D FEA.
10.2. Multi-port Network – 2
We now consider a SIMO system having ﬁve outlet-ports
as shown in Fig. 10, with the inlet-port denoted by P1 and the
outlet-ports denoted by ports P2–P6. It consists of a network of
2-port elements and a multi-port element, marked as MP1. The
system is excited at one of the ports of element MP1, while the
remaining ports are the outlet-ports. The computed TL charac-
teristics are shown in Fig. 11, where one observes that the axial
plane wave analysis shows a reasonable agreement with the 3-
D FEA up to about 1340 Hz (approximate cut-on frequency of
the (1, 0) mode for the element MP1), beyond which there is
a signiﬁcant deviation between the two approaches. One ob-
serves a similarity between the nature of the TL characteristics
of an expansion chamber and the nature of the network shown
in Fig. 10 in the low frequency region.
10.3. Multi-port Network – 3
A more complicated and intricate network of a SIMO sys-
tem having two outlet-ports is considered in Fig. 12a, and
the location of the inlet (P1) and outlets (P2 and P3) are also
shown. This network consists of three multi-port elements
(marked MP1, MP2, and MP3 in Fig. 12a) with the elements
MP2 and MP3 each having seven ports, the element MP1 hav-
ing three ports, and the remaining elements being 2-port ele-
ments. A 3-D view of this network is also shown in Fig. 12b.
The TL graph for this conﬁguration is shown in Fig. 13 and is
characterized by the presence of several resonance peaks oc-
curring because of phase cancellations due to unequal lengths

of the connecting pipes, as well as the location of one of the
outlet-ports on the same side as the inlet-ports. It is interesting
to note that even though the cut-on frequency of the (1, 0) mode
(corresponding to MP2 and MP3, which have the largest diam-
eter amongst all the elements in this conﬁguration) is 2010 Hz
approximately, there is a signiﬁcant deviation between the ax-
ial plane wave and 3-D FEA predictions between the frequency
band of 800 Hz to 1100 Hz. This shift in the resonance peak
frequency around 1000 Hz is most likely attributed to the ef-
fects of the higher order evanescent modes. It is also important
to note that the end correction expressions used in this work
are only approximate, since the frequency dependence is not
taken into account. Hence, one may expect some discrepancy
in the axial plane wave and the 3-D FEA, even when the end
corrections are considered and when one is in the frequency
region that supports the propagation of only the axial mode.
This discrepancy can be attributed to the presence of several
area discontinuities (corresponding to the number of ports) at
the end faces and side surfaces of long chambers wherein the
acoustic waves are essentially nonplanar due to the existence
of higher order evanescent modes near the ports of a chamber,
see Karal.21 Nevertheless, the advantage of axial plane wave
analysis is a computationally fast and reasonable ﬁrst approxi-
mation of the TL characteristics.
Figure 15. Acoustic performance for the conﬁguration corresponding to
Multi-port Network – 4 shown in Fig. 14: Validation of axial plane wave anal-
ysis with 3-D FEA.
10.4. Multi-port Network – 4
Finally, we consider a network arrangement of a MIMO sys-
tem having two inlets (P1 and P2) and ﬁve outlets (P3–P7),
as shown in Fig. 14. This consists of two multi-port ele-
ments marked as MP1 (having ﬁve ports) and MP2 (having
six ports), which are connected by 2-port elements. The ra-
tio of the incident wave amplitudes at the two inlet-ports is
λ12 =A2/A1=−1, so that the two incident waves are ex-
actly out of phase with each other. Moreover, the character-
istic impedances of these ports are also equal (both the ports
have the same diameters). Therefore, one should expect a res-
onance peak in the very low frequency region, which is indeed
the case as seen in Fig. 15 wherein the TL tends to inﬁnity
near 0 Hz. Moreover, the agreement between the axial plane
predictions as well as 3-D FEA is satisfactory up to about 1200
Hz, beyond which a signiﬁcant deviation is observed between
the two approaches. This can be explained by noticing that as
one approaches the cut-on frequency for (1, 0) mode (which
is approximately about 1607 Hz for the elements MP1 and
MP2), the higher order evanescent modes, in particular, the
(1, 0) mode, begin to acquire a propagating part, and thence
start to signiﬁcantly inﬂuence the acoustic pressure ﬁeld inside
the elements MP1 and MP2. As a result, the acoustic pressure
ﬁeld predicted by the 1-D axial plane wave model is substan-

A. Mimani, et al.: ACOUSTICAL ANALYSIS OF A GENERAL NETWORK OF MULTI-PORT ELEMENTS. . .

l4= 0.1m, l5= 0.15 m, l6= 0.05 m, l7= 0.07854 m, l8= 0.4993 m, l9= 0.2m, l10 = 0.3345 m, l11 = 0.4993 m, l12 = 0.2513 m, l13 = 0.15 m,

tially different from that predicted by considering the more ac-
curate and realistic 3-D wave propagation model; thereby the
[Z] parameters, and hence the TL graph obtained by the 1-D
approach, is expected to deviate from the corresponding 3-D
FEA results. Furthermore, for the present conﬁguration, the
accuracy of the TL values obtained by 1-D axial plane wave
theory for frequencies beyond the cut-on frequency of the (1,
0) mode is questionable, inasmuch as the terms corresponding
to the (1, 0) mode have been neglected while computing the
[Z] parameters. In general, one can safely conclude that the
TL predicted by the 1-D axial plane wave model should not
be taken very seriously for frequencies approaching the cut-
on frequency of the ﬁrst higher order propagating mode, and
obviously for frequencies beyond that mode.
10.5. Validation Against the Previous Works
in the Literature
The axial plane wave analysis presented here, for a network
of multi-port elements may also be validated against some of
the cases in which a single multi-port element is analyzed and
also against the modiﬁed Herschel-Quincke tube (three-duct)
conﬁguration analyzed by Selamet and Easwaran.4
10.5.1. Expansion Chamber with Two End-Inlets and
One Side-Outlet
We ﬁrst consider an axially long expansion chamber ana-
lyzed by Selamet and Ji consisting of two end-inlets and one
side-outlet,9wherein the 1-D axial plane wave approach is em-
Figure 16. Validation of 1-D axial plane wave analysis with the 3-D BEM
based analysis for the mufﬂer conﬁguration shown in Fig. 1 of Selamet and Ji
(Reference 9) with the following dimensions: d1=d2= 0.0486 m, d3=
0.0584 m, d= 0.1532 m, l= 0.54 m, l1= 0.4725 m, l2= 0.0675 m.
ployed to obtain an expression for the amplitude of progressive
wave propagating downstream, (i.e., B3as a linear combina-
tion of the incident wave A1and A2at the two end-inlets),
although the [Z] matrix approach presented in this work is not
employed. The authors compare their prediction against the
3-D BEM predictions. Thus, one of the aims of this work is
also to extend the work on axial plane wave analysis for long
chambers having two inlets, ﬁrst reported by Selamet and Ji,9
to analyze a multi-port element having an arbitrary number of
inlet and outlet-ports by means of [Z] matrix, using the ax-
ial plane wave theory. Thus, for the purpose of validating the
[Z] matrix approach in this work, we consider one of the cases
in Selamet and Ji9where the incident waves at the end-ports
are completely out of phase, (i.e., A2/A1=−1). The con-
